column4: I am not sure why this is showing up in my /var/log/auth.log .....Jun 14 12:17:01 drake CRON[10809] : (pam_unix) session opened for user root by (uid=0) Jun 14 12:17:01 drake CRON[10809] : (pam_unix) session closed for user root
a cron job is running as root.
is that something that is run by default with an ssh server? or something that was manually done?
well, its a cron job, so check what you have running in the cron for midnight.
it apparently has been running every hour on the 17th minute and first second for days
well, all system-wide ones. Individual user's cron jobs are in their own crontab
there is actually nothing strange about that :)
is that what is causing the ssh server to be listening for a root login?
where did you get that idea?

this is what I am trying to find the source that is causing this Jun 16 15:17:01 drake CRON[21933] : (pam_unix) session opened for user root by (uid=0) Jun 16 15:17:01 drake CRON[21933] : (pam_unix) session closed for user root
its the CRON job I think.
I was trying to find which cron was causing it to happen and more importantly why is it necessary if it is necessary
I think its the anacron job that is checking for other entries to run at the hourly cron.
there is nothing in /etc/cron.hourly except a file called .placeholder that simply says # This file is a simple placeholder to keep dpkg from removing this directory
check /etc/crontab

I see there entries in /etc/crontab # m h dom mon dow user  command 17 *    * * *   root    run-parts --report /etc/cron.hourly 25 6    * * *   root    test -x /usr/sbin/anacron || run-parts --report /etc/cron.daily 47 6    * * 7   root    test -x /usr/sbin/anacron || run-parts --report /etc/cron.weekly 52 6    1 * *   root    test -x /usr/sbin/anacron || run-parts --report /etc/cron.monthly
your log entry mystery is from the first crontab entry, that executes every 17 minutes.
the command being run by cron is "run-parts" just like the other jobs are running a command called "test"?
yes, but its running as root, so that's why there is a root session login.
is that something that is default on an ubuntu install or something that has been added manually?
that can't be a good idea to be running a cron job listening for a root ssh connection, can it?
said that it was being run by something in the crontab but I haven't been able to pin down what is actually calling that particular command to be done
